141.01 DEFINITIONS.
   Except where the context requires otherwise, the following expressions
wherever used in this chapter shall be read with the meanings here given to
them:
   (a)   "City service" includes all officers and employees of the departments
and other agencies of the government of the City except the members of boards
and commissions and such elected officers or employees whose compensation may
be fixed by statute, incumbents of positions whose compensation cannot be
changed during their terms of office, and those who are elected to positions in
the government of the City as provided by the statutes of the State.
   (b)   "Class" or "class of positions" means a definitely recognized kind of
employment represented by one or more positions in the service of the City so
nearly alike in the essential character of their duties, responsibilities and
consequent qualification requirements, that they may, with equity, be treated
alike for employment and compensation purposes.
   (c)   "Definitions of classes" means the official descriptions in terms of
duties, responsibilities and minimum qualification requirements, of the several
classes comprising the classification plan.
   (d)   "Employee" means any incumbent of a position as defined herein.
   (e)   "Position" means an office or employment, or combination of two or
more of them, involving an aggregation of duties to be performed and
responsibilities to be exercised by one person.
      (Ord. 168-1958. Passed 10-20-58.)
141.02 ADOPTION OF CLASSIFICATION AND COMPENSATION.
   The plan of classification and compensation of positions set forth by
ordinances of Council from time to time is made a part hereof by reference
thereto as though fully rewritten herein, and the scales of compensation there
provided for the several classes, are adopted to govern employment and
compensation in all positions in the City service, in the manner herein
provided. (Ord. 168-1958. Passed 10-20-58.)
141.03 ADMINISTRATION OF PLAN.
   The provisions of this chapter shall be administered by the Mayor with the
assistance of the directors of the departments and heads of other agencies.
(Ord. 168-1958. Passed 10-20-58.)
141.04 TITLES OF POSITIONS.
   The title of each class as set forth in the consolidated personnel
classification plan established by ordinance shall be the official title of
every position allocated to the class as hereinafter provided, to be used on
all payrolls, budget estimates, and official records and reports relating to
the position as such, but other titles may be used for departmental and other
purposes. Except as herein provided, no person shall be appointed, employed or
paid under any title other than that of the class to which the position
occupied has been allocated under the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 168-1958. Passed 10-20-58.)
141.05 DEFINITIONS OF CLASSES.
   The Mayor shall provide, and may change from time to time, definitions for
each class, which definitions shall define the class in terms of the duties and
responsibilities that distinguish positions of the class from those of other
classes; and shall require that an accurate and complete set of all definitions
in effect be kept, and copies thereof furnished to the head of each department
and other agencies in the City service.
   The definitions for each class so provided shall be construed as descriptive
and explanatory only and not prescriptive nor restrictive. Its purpose and use
shall be merely to indicate the kinds of positions that should be allocated to
the class as determined by their duties and responsibilities, and not to
prescribe what the duties and responsibilities of any position shall be. (Ord.
168-1958. Passed 10-20-58.)
141.06 ALLOCATION OF POSITIONS TO CLASSES.
   The Mayor, in consultation with the heads of the several departments and
other agencies, shall have the head of each department or other agency allocate
each position now existing, and each position hereafter created in the City
service to its appropriate class within such time as the Mayor may prescribe,
and the head of each department or other agency may re-allocate positions from
class to class, with the approval of the Mayor, which the Mayor shall certify
to the Director of Finance.
   Whenever the duties of a position are so changed that the position in effect
becomes one of a different class from that to which it has been allocated, such
change shall operate to abolish the position and to create a new position of
such different class.
   Each appointing officer shall report to the Mayor, in such manner as the
Mayor may prescribe, the duties of each new position and every material change
in the duties of an existing position that might warrant a change in
allocation.
   The Mayor shall cause to be reviewed the duties and responsibilities of all
positions in the City service from time to time with a view to determining
whether re-allocation of positions from class to class, by reason of the duties
and responsibilities of such positions, should be made.
   The assignment of duties in any position, different from those ordinarily
pertaining to the class to which such position is allocated, to be performed
incidentally and in addition to the regular duties of the position, or to be
performed temporarily in lieu thereof, shall not be deemed to require the re-
allocation of such position to a different class.
(Ord. 168-1958. Passed 10-20-58.)
141.07 COMPENSATION.
   Upon and after the approval by the Mayor of allocations of positions to
their respective classes, no employee in the City service shall be paid any
compensation except in accordance with the provisions of this chapter.
   The Director of Finance shall verify and approve the rate of pay for each
employee as to compliance with the provisions of this chapter and shall certify
each rate so determined to the Mayor, before such rate shall become effective,
and shall give notice to the Mayor of each new employee added to the payrolls
by any department or agency each month.
(Ord. 168-1958. Passed 10-20-58.)
141.08 APPOINTMENTS AT MINIMUM RATES OF SCALES.
   The rate of pay of any employee on appointment to any position shall be the
mimimum rate of the scale for the class to which the position is allocated;
provided, however, that under circumstances where the prospective employee
possesses superior qualifications for the position to which he is to be
appointed or where it is necessary to offer him a higher salary than that of
the mimimum rate for the class to which the position is allocated in order to
induce him to enter the City service, the Mayor, after stating in writing his
reasons therefor, may appoint or authorize an appointment at any rate within
the scale for the class to which the position has been allocated; and provided
further, that where a person already in the service is transferred, demoted, or
promoted to, or a former employee is re-employed in a position, he shall be
paid at the same rates as in his former position, if there be such a rate in
the scale for the class of the new position, and if not, at the rate next
higher than his former rate and, if there be no such higher rate, then the
maximum rate for the class.
    Notwithstanding any other provisions of this chapter, persons employed in
skilled and common labor positions on a basis of time actually engaged and
without allowances for absence from work, may be paid at hourly rates related
as closely as may be practicable to the minimum rates of the scales provided
under this chapter, such rates to be determined by the Mayor on the
recommendations of the heads of departments and other agencies. The head of a
department or other agency with the approval of the Mayor, may employ a person
for a trial period of not to exceed six months at such rate of pay below the
minimum rate of the scale for the class, as the head of the department or other
agency may determine. (Ord. 168-1958. Passed 10-20-58.)
141.09 INCREASES IN COMPENSATION WITHIN THE SCALES.
   Subject to the appropriations provided, and after consultation with the
Director of Finance, successive increases in the compensation of any employee
may be made from rate to rate within the scale for his class, up to and
including the maximum rate of the scale, upon recommendation of the head of the
department or other agency, with the approval of the Mayor, at any time after
the expiration of one full year of meritorious service at his then present rate
of the scale. The approval of the Mayor shall be based on such evidence secured
through investigation or otherwise as he may deem necessary to satisfy him that
the employee proposed for advancement in rate has, in fact, earned such
advancement by reason of faithful and efficient service in performing the
duties of the position. (Ord. 168- 1958. Passed 10-20-58.)
141.10 DECREASES IN COMPENSATION.
   The head of any department or other agency who is dissatisfied with the
character of work of an employee in a position of any class, may recommend to
the Mayor a decrease in the rate of compensation of such employee to any lower
rate in the scale for the class. The Mayor, after such investigation as may be
sufficient to satisfy him that the facts justify the decreases recommended, may
approve the recommendation so made and fix the rate to be paid at the lower
rate in the scale for the class as recommended. The Mayor may of his own accord
make such investigation and reduction in any case in which he may deem such
action justified, and shall notify the head of the department or agency of such
action. (Ord. 168-1958. Passed 10-20-58.)
141.11 PROMOTIONS, TRANSFERS, DEMOTIONS AND REMOVALS.
   Any employee may be promoted from a position of one class to any vacancy
existing in a position of a higher class when in the judgment of the appointing
officer, the employee has the necessary qualifications to fit him for the
duties of a position of such higher class, in accordance with any provisions of
the civil service statutes if the employee be classified under such statutes,
under the same conditions as the appointing officer is authorized to make any
new appointment to the position of such higher class.
   The head of any department or other agency, likewise may transfer any
employee from any position to any vacancy existing in any other position that
such employee is deemed qualified to fill, under like conditions.
   Whenever any employee is deemed by the head of the department or other
agency in which he is employed, to be unable or unwilling to perform the duties
of the position occupied by him in a satisfactory manner, by reason of physical
disability of a temporary or permanent character resulting from accident or
illness or other cause, or for any other reason, the head of the department or
other agency may cause such employee to be demoted to any position of a lower
class in which a vacancy exists that the employee is deemed competent to fill.
In such a case the rate of pay shall be fixed at such rate of the scale for
such lower class as may be applicable under the provisions of this chapter.
   Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to limit or affect any authority
to remove or dismiss any employee from the City service heretofore possessed by
any officer.
   Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to limit, abrogate, change or
affect the rights, privileges, benefits, or limitations created or imposed by
the civil service laws of the State. (Ord. 168-1958. Passed 10-20-58.)
141.12 EFFECT OF MAXIMUM RATE.
   The maximum rate in the scale for any class shall be the highest rate
payable to any employee in any position of the class.
(Ord. 168-1958. Passed 10-20-58.)
141.13 RATES ARE FOR FULL-TIME EMPLOYMENT.
   The rates of pay prescribed by this chapter shall be taken to represent the
standard rates of pay for full-time employment for the regularly established
working hours, and subject to such provisions for authorized leaves of absence
as may be prescribed. When part-time service is authorized or rendered
involving less than the regularly established number of hours of service in any
period, the actual compensation to be paid shall be determined by the relation
that the actual number of hours of service authorized and rendered bears to the
number of hours of service involved in full-time employment, due allowance
being made for officially recognized holidays and authorized leaves of absence.
The Director of Finance with the approval of the Mayor, shall determine and fix
the divisor to be used in establishing such ratio.
(Ord. 168-1958. Passed 10-20-58.)
141.14 PAYMENT AT RATES BASED ON TIME UNIT OTHER THAN THE YEAR.
   Each rate of pay set forth in the pay range schedule shall be taken to
represent the amount payable for a full year of service. It shall be
permissible to pay equivalent compensation on any other basis when the interest
of the service so requires, but the rate to be paid for any other time unit
shall be determined by division of the standard annual rate payable, by the
number of such other time units in a full year of employment, as specified by
the Director of Finance with the approval of the Mayor.
(Ord. 168-1958. Passed 10-20-58.)
141.15 ADJUSTMENT FOR ALLOWANCES.
   In any case in which any allowance is provided in addition to the base
salary paid, such as of meals, lodging, living quarters, and the like,
including maintenance provided for others on behalf of the employee, but not
including reimbursement of actual and necessary expenses authorized and
incurred as incidents to the employment, such allowance shall be treated as
compensation in kind, involving part payment of the salary prescribed, to be
deducted from the amount of money actually payable to the extent of their fair
cash value as appraised and fixed by the Director of Finance with the approval
of the Mayor.
(Ord. 168-1958. Passed 10-20-58.)
141.16 PART PAYMENT FROM OTHER SOURCES.
   Whenever part of the compensation for the performance of the duties of any
position in the City service is paid from a different appropriation, fund, or
account, from that or from which any other part of the compensation for such
position is paid, or is derived from any agency outside the City service, all
such part payments shall be deducted from the amounts payable under the rate
prescribed so that the total compensation for the position from all sources for
any period shall not exceed the amount payable under the rate prescribed under
the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 168-1958. Passed 10-20-58.)
141.17 NO EXTRA PAYMENT EXCEPT AS AUTHORIZED FOR OVERTIME.
   No payment in excess of the amount authorized hereunder, as determined by
the rate prescribed, shall be made to any employee in respect to any service
rendered by him, either in the discharge of his ordinary duties, or in the
performance of any other duties imposed upon him or assumed by him, except as
may be provided by due authority in payment for overtime work in excess of the
hours required for full-time employment.
(Ord. 168-1958. Passed 10-20-58.)
141.18 STANDARDIZATION OF ATTENDANCE AND ABSENCE REQUIREMENTS.
   The head of each department or other agency, subject to the approval of the
Mayor, shall prescribe by regulations, standard hours of service and leaves of
absence to apply throughout his department or agency, and for standard
procedures for the control of attendance and absence. The standards so
established shall be uniform in their application to all employees in the City
service under like conditions, but may vary among different groups whose work
is done under different employment conditions.
(Ord. 168-1958. Passed 10-20-58.)
141.19 ADJUSTMENT OF EXISTING RATES TO NEW SCALES.
   At the time of the taking effect of this chapter, or of any ordinance
hereafter adopted establishing or changing the rate or scale of rates for any
class in pursuance of the classification and compensation plan adopted, the
rate of pay of each employee in a position of any class affected shall be
adjusted, subject to the available appropriations, as follows:
   (a)   The rate of pay of any employee receiving less than the minimum rate
of the scale prescribed for his class, shall forthwith be increased to such
rate.
   (b)   The rate of pay of any employee who is paid at any one of the
specified rates of the scale prescribed for his class, shall not be changed by
reason of the new rate or scale adopted.
   (c)   The rate of pay of any employee who is paid at a rate between the
minimum and the maximum rate of the scale prescribed for his class, but not
corresponding with any specified intermediate rate of such scale, shall
forthwith be adjusted to the nearest rate of such scale.
   (d)   The rate of pay of any employee who is receiving more than the maximum
rate of the scale prescribed for his class may be reduced to such maximum rate,
but the head of each department or other agency shall endeavor with diligence
to provide by transfer or promotion, for placing such employee in a position of
such higher class as will
provide the rate of pay then received or one more nearly approximate
thereto, and for which the employee concerned shall be found to be qualified.
(Ord. 168-1958. Passed 10-20-58.)
 
141.20 COFFEE, MEALS, ETC.
   The Chief Fiscal Officer, upon proper appropriation, is authorized to pay
for coffee, meals, refreshments and other amenities which are considered fringe
benefits for municipal officers and employees of the City.
(Ord. 11-2023. Passed 2-13-23.)

143.01 MILEAGE ALLOWANCE.
   (a)   Subject to subsection (c) hereof, the Director of Finance is
authorized and directed to reimburse, upon receipt of a statement for such
mileage incurred, those City employees and officials, whether elected or
appointed, who are required to use their own personal automobiles, on out-of-
town business for the City, at the rate equal to the maximum number of cents
per mile authorized by the Internal Revenue Service pursuant to Revenue
Procedure 82-61, as modified, supplemented or amended from time to time, and
any law, regulating Revenue Ruling, Revenue Procedure, or other pronouncement
that may supersede Revenue Procedure 82-61.
   (b)   No City employees or officials shall use their own personal
automobiles on such mileage basis unless authorized by their department head,
and/or the Mayor. Such authorization shall be made on forms provided by the
Director of Finance, with his certification that funds are available for the
expenses of such trip or trips.
 
   (c)   Mileage reimbursed to Deputy Bailiffs and other officials serving
Court notices and capiases may only be paid from the Municipal Court Revolving
Capias Fund established for this purpose. (Ord. 13-1989. Passed 2-13-89.)
143.02 RESIDENCE REQUIREMENTS; VIOLATION.
   (a)   All members and employees of City departments shall be required to
reside within a fifteen-mile radius of the City. These requirements shall not
apply to members who have been given permission by their department head or the
Mayor to live outside these limits and who reside outside of the City as of
September 12, 1960, and to personnel with special or professional training or
qualifications, such as engineers, lawyers, doctors, nurses, surveyors,
architects and persons of special training and qualifications.
 
   (b)   Anyone violating any provision of this section shall forfeit any
remuneration or emoluments received following such failure to comply with such
provisions and shall immediately upon demand repay to the Director of Finance,
all moneys, remunerations or emoluments received following such removal from
the City. Upon notice of the violation of this section, the Director of Law
shall herewith institute civil proceedings for the refund of moneys illegally
paid to such employee as provided in this section.
(Ord. 61-1988. Passed 9-12-88.)
143.03 WORK PROCEDURES AND HOURS.
   (a)   The work week for the employees of the City except for employees of
the Fire Division shall be a forty-hour work week, Monday through Saturday,
with a basic eight-hour day. The work week for employees of the Fire Division
shall be 2,800 hours per year.
(Ord. 17-1982. Passed 12-20-82.)
 
   (b)   The City does not recognize a regular or quitting time in view of the
many complexities of operation by employees of the City. Employees may be
required to begin their work day at varying hours or shifts. For any time
worked in excess of eight hours in any one work day, compensation shall be made
at the rate of one and one-half times the hourly rate otherwise fixed by
ordinance for such work.
 
   (c)    For any work days actually worked in excess of the regular work week
as described in subsection (a) hereof, compensation shall be made at the rate
of one and one-half times the hourly rate fixed by ordinance for such work.
 
   (d)   Holidays, birthdays and sick leave taken, whether for actual illness
or for death in the immediate family are not to be understood as a working day.
 
   (e)   Vacation pay shall be based on a forty-hour week except as otherwise
provided.
 
   (f)   Birthdays, when permitted or authorized as a fringe benefit day, must
be taken on the actual birthday. Such birthdays are not considered a working
day and shall be compensated only on a straight-time basis.
   (g)   Sick leave shall be credited as provided by ordinance. No advance sick
leave shall be permitted to any employee.
 
   (h)   When an employee is called in to work at other than his regular work
time, he shall be authorized a minimum of two hours as show-up time even though
he actually worked less than two hours.
 
   (i)   Employees that are called out and required to work on snow and ice
removal crews by the Mayor, the Service Director or their designee, shall be
compensated at the rate of time and one-half for all hours worked before 8:00
a.m. or after 4:30 p.m. in any given twenty-four hour period. All hours worked
on snow and ice removal during the regular work day, that is, from 8:00 a.m. to
4:30 p.m. shall be paid at regular rate and shall not receive time and one-half
for hours worked during the regular work day regardless of the hours they have
worked during a given twenty-four hour period.
(Ord. 141-1971. Passed 10-11-71; Ord. 16-1973. Passed 2-26-73.)
143.04 COMPULSORY RETIREMENT; EMPLOYEES IN CITY SERVICE.
   (a)   All employees in the City service except members of the Police and
Fire Divisions, school guards and part-time employees shall not continue their
employment after attaining their sixty-fifth birthday.
 
   (b)   All employees affected in subsection (a) hereof upon reaching the age
of sixty- five years, at the request of their department head and the approval
of the Mayor, may extend their employment for one year.
(Ord. 67-1972. Passed 9-11-72; Ord. 72-1972. Passed 9-25-72.)
143.05 PAYMENT ON BI-WEEKLY BASIS.
   All employees of the City, except as otherwise provided by the Ohio Revised
Code, shall receive their respective authorized compensation every two weeks,
twenty-six or twenty- seven times per year, and in the years containing twenty-
seven pay periods, payment shall not be deemed to be in excess of authorized
annual compensation.
(Ord. 51-1999. Passed 6-14-99.)
143.06 COMPENSATION FOR LEAVE OF ABSENCE FOR TEMPORARY MILITARY ACTIVE DUTY.
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: See also the Personnel Policies and Procedures Manual for
legislation pertaining to City employees called to active duty in the military
services.)
   (a)   All City employees who are members of the Ohio National Guard, The
Ohio State Guard, the Ohio Naval Militia or other reserve components of the
Armed Forces of the United States shall be entitled to leave of absence from
their respective duties for such time as they are in such military service on
field training or active duty for periods not to exceed thirty-one days in any
calendar year.
 
   (b)   If a City employee's military pay or compensation during such period
of leave of absence is less than his City pay would have been for such period,
he shall be paid by the City the difference in money between the City pay and
his military pay for such period. In determining such employee's military pay
for the purposes of this section allowances for travel, food or housing shall
not be considered, but any other pay or allowances of whatever nature,
including longevity pay, shall be considered.
(Ord. 44-1986. Passed 8-11-86.)
143.07 UNIFORM ALLOWANCE.
   All City employees whose classifications include Chief Police Dispatcher,
Police Dispatcher, Records Clerk or Jailer shall be entitled to receive from
the City the sum of two hundred and fifty dollars ($250.00) per annum, payable
on December 1 of every calendar year as a uniform clothing allowance.
(Ord. 13-1988. Passed 3-21-88.)
143.08 LONGEVITY.
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Legislation pertaining to longevity pay is now contained in
the Personnel Policies and Procedures Manual.)
143.09 TIME UTILIZATION COMPENSATION.
   All full-time City employees not otherwise covered by a collective
bargaining agreement and excluding elected or appointed officials, shall be
entitled to receive the sum of three hundred dollars ($300.00) for time
utilization compensation pursuant to the following terms:
   (a)   The head of the department in which such employee is employed notifies
the Mayor and Finance Director in writing that the employee has had perfect
attendance for the calendar year beginning December 1 and ending November 30.
   (b)   The employee shall have been employed on a full-time basis for the
entire calendar year.
   (c)   Such time utilization compensation shall be paid by the City to the
employee on December 10 or the first working day thereafter, if December 10
falls on a nonworking day.
      (Ord. 13-1988. Passed 3-21-88.)
143.10 DEFENSE OF EMPLOYEES AGAINST LIABILITY CLAIMS.
   (a)   To the extent allowed by law, the City shall provide for the legal
defense of any of its elected or appointed officials, officers or employees, or
any former official, officer or employee, in any local, county, state or
federal court, in any civil action or proceeding to recover damages for injury,
death or loss to persons or property allegedly caused by an act or omission of
such officials, officers or employees, if the act or omission occurred during
the course of their official duties or employment and such officials, officers
or employees were acting in good faith.
 
   (b)   To the extent allowed by law, the City shall indemnify and hold
harmless any of its current or former elected or appointed officials, officers
or employees, or any former officials, officers or employees, in the amount of
any judgment or settlement, other than a judgment for punitive or exemplary
damages, against such officials, officers or employees in a state or federal
court, for damages for injury, death or loss to persons or property caused by
any act or omission of such officials, officers or employees if the act or
omission occurred during the course of their official duties or employment and
such officials, officers or employees were acting in good faith.
   (c)   The City, in providing for the defense and indemnification of its
current and former officials, officers or employees as set forth in this
section, reserves the right to enter into a consent, judgment or settlement,
and to secure releases from liability, for itself and any such officials,
officers or employees, as the City shall determine, which determination shall
be final.
   (d)   The City, in providing for the defense and indemnification of its
current and former officials, officers or employees as set forth in this
section, reserves the right to determine and retain legal counsel of its
choosing and at its expense for the purpose of representing such current and
former officials, officers or employees; provided, however, that such
officials, officers or employees may retain their own additional legal counsel,
at their sole expense, who may act as co-counsel in their defense, provided
further that determinations regarding the defense or settlement of a claim
shall remain solely with the City and its appointed counsel.
   (e)   This section shall not apply to the following:
      (1)   Civil actions or claims by a City official, officer or employee, or
the collective bargaining representative of an employee, against the City, or
by the city against an official, officer or employee or collective bargaining
representative, relative to any matter arising out of the employment
relationship between the official, officer or employee and the city, including,
but not limited to, disciplinary matters, grievances, workers' compensation
claims, unemployment compensation claims or civil service matters, or by the
City against an official, officer or employee or collective bargaining
representative relative to any action by the City to recover moneys and/or
damages.
      (2)   Criminal actions or proceedings. (Ord. 103-1991. Passed 9-23-91.)
143.11 LIABILITY FOR RETURN OF CITY PROPERTY.
   (a)   Any City Council person, Council President, or any other elected or
appointed official who is given, or presented City-issued property, such as
electronic equipment, or a copy of the Codified Ordinances of the City of
Garfield Heights for use in the course of his or her employment shall be
responsible for its return upon the leaving of City employment, retirement,
dismissal, expulsion, or end of term of office or the like.
 
      (b)    Whoever violates the provisions of Section
143.11 shall be held liable for the expense of said property and all costs of
collection of amounts due to the City.
(Ord. 80-2020. Passed 10-26-20.)
143.12 NEPOTISM.
   Employment by the City of two or more relatives is permissible, provided
that:
   (a)   Employment is in accordance with the Ohio Ethics Law and related
statutes found in Ohio Revised Code Chapter 102, and Section 2921.42; and
   (b)   Neither of the related persons is in a position to supervise or
otherwise influence the work assignments, working conditions, promotion or
compensation of the other; and
   (c)   The relationship is disclosed in writing to the Mayor and the
appropriate department head(s) prior to employment.
   (d)   For purposes of this section, “relative” shall mean an individual’s:
      (1)   Spouse or domestic partner;
      (2)   Children (whether dependent or not);
      (3)   Siblings;
      (4)   Parents;
      (5)   Grandparents; and
      (6)   Grandchildren; and
      (7)   Any other person related by blood or by marriage and living in the
same household.
   Any conflicts between this section and the rules for hiring Civil Service
employees shall be resolved in favor of the rules for hiring Civil Service
employees.
(Ord. 14-2024. Passed 3-25-24.)
143.13 DRUG-FREE WORKPLACE POLICY AND PROCEDURES.
   The Drug-Free Workplace Policy and Procedures attached to Resolution 13-2008
and labeled “Exhibit A” is hereby adopted.
(Res. 13-2008. Passed 3-24-08.)
143.99 PENALTY.
   Any person violating the provisions of Section
143.02 or any person in a supervisory position who knowingly permits an
employee to be in violation of Section
143.02 is guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree.
CHAPTER 147
Conflict of Interest
147.01     Contract work concerning City; advantageous office.
147.02     Appearance to be without compensation.
147.03     Legal controversy in which City is a party.
147.04     Activities within one year after City employment.
147.99     Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCE
Contract interest - see GEN. OFF.
525.10
 
 
147.01 CONTRACT WORK CONCERNING CITY; ADVANTAGEOUS OFFICE.
   No elected or appointed official, member of Council, member of any board,
officer or employee of the City shall:
   (a)   Act directly or indirectly as attorney, agent, engineer, broker or
employee for any person, firm, association, partnership or corporation
interested directly or indirectly in any manner whatsoever in any contract work
or business with the City, or the sale or acquisition of any property owned or
controlled by the City;
   (b)   Act directly or indirectly as attorney, agent, engineer, broker or
employee for any person, firm, association, partnership or corporation
interested directly or indirectly in any manner whatsoever in any contract work
or business for two or more parties whereby the City is one party thereof;
   (c)   Hold office where it would be advantageous to any elected or appointed
official financially, other than the compensation fixed for the position so
held.
      (Ord. 91-1964. Passed 6-22-64.)
147.02 APPEARANCE TO BE WITHOUT COMPENSATION.
   No elected or appointed official, member of Council, member of any board,
officer or employee of the City shall appear before any board or commission of
the City as counsel, attorney, engineer or agent, except on behalf of
constituents without compensation therefor, or in the performance of public
obligation or official duties.
(Ord. 91-1964. Passed 6-22-64.)
147.03 LEGAL CONTROVERSY IN WHICH CITY IS A PARTY.
   No elected or appointed official, member of Council, member of any board,
officer or employee of the City shall engage in the practice of law before the
Municipal Court in any matter or controversy in which the City is or may become
a party except on behalf of the City as an officer or employee, or give opinion
evidence against the interest of the City in any litigation in which the City
is a party.
(Ord. 91-1964. Passed 6-22-64.)
147.04 ACTIVITIES WITHIN ONE YEAR AFTER CITY EMPLOYMENT.
   No elected or appointed official, member of Council, member of any board,
officer or employee of the City shall appear within a period of one year after
termination of his services as an officer or employee of the City, before any
board or commission of the City as counsel, attorney, engineer or agent, for or
in behalf of any person, firm, association, partnership or corporation, or
receive compensation for any services rendered thereto, in relation to any
matter which was under his charge or jurisdiction during the period of his
services as such officer, member or employee.
(Ord. 91-1964. Passed 6-22-64.)
147.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates the provisions of Section
147.01 shall forfeit his position and be removed from office.
   Whoever violates any provision of Sections
147.02 to
147.04 is guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree and shall forfeit his
office .
TITLE NINE - Judicial
Chap.
161. Municipal Court.
CHAPTER 161
Municipal Court
   EDITOR'S NOTE: The Garfield Heights Municipal Court having territorial
jurisdiction within the City and within the municipal corporations of Maple
Heights, Walton Hills, Valley View, Cuyahoga Heights, Newburgh Heights,
Independence and Brecksville, has been established under Ohio R.C. 1901.01 et
seq. Ohio R.C. 1901.25 provides that the Municipal Court may provide by rule
how jurors shall be chosen. Jurors' fees in any criminal case involving the
violation of a City ordinance shall be paid out of the City Treasury. The
Municipal Court, pursuant to Ohio R.C. 1901.26(A), may establish a schedule of
fees and costs to be taxed in any action or proceeding, whether civil or
criminal. Ohio R.C. 1901.31(F) provides that fines received for violation of
Garfield Heights ordinances shall be paid into the City Treasury. Rule 13 of
the Ohio Traffic Rules as promulgated by the Ohio Supreme Court provides that a
court shall establish a traffic violations bureau and specifies certain
restrictions as to the designated offenses and schedule of fines to be accepted
as waiver payment in lieu of court appearance.

Record of traffic violations - see Ohio R.C. 4513.37
