income and expenditure shall include and accurately show the itemized fund-
raising cost of the organization. In the case of any national or statewide
organization, the financial statements shall include such departmentalization
as to accurately and clearly show income and expenditures, including fund-
raising costs allocable to activities within the City.
      (l)   A full statement of the character and extent of religious
solicitation of funds being done by the applicant within the City.
      (m)   Such other information as may be required by the Finance Director
in order to determine the kind and character of the proposed solicitation and
the persons connected therewith.
      If while any application is pending or during the term of any Certificate
of Registration granted thereon, there is any change in fact, policy, or method
that would alter the information given in the application, the applicant shall
notify the Commissioner in writing thereof within twenty-four hours after such
change.
      Upon receipt of such application, the Building Commissioner shall without
undue delay commence to investigate the affairs of the applicant and cause to
have verified the information submitted by the applicant. Upon completion of
processing of the application and related detail and verification thereof, the
Commissioner shall issue the applicant a Certificate of Registration. The
Certificate shall remain in force and effect for a period of not more than one
year after the issuance thereof. Certificates of Registration for religious
solicitation of funds shall bear the name and address of the person by whom the
solicitation is to be made, the number of the Certificate, the date issued and
a statement that the Certificate does not constitute an endorsement by the City
of the purpose of the solicitation.
(Ord. 78-2021. Passed 10-12-21.)
707.16 CREDENTIALS FOR SOLICITORS OF RELIGIOUS SOLICITATIONS.
      All persons to whom Certificates of Registration have been issued shall
comply with the applicable provisions of Section
707.03. No person shall solicit funds or contributions for any religious cause
without having such credentials on his person, and such person shall, upon
demand, present these credentials to any person solicited or to any police
officer of the City.
(Ord. 78-2021. Passed 10-12-21.)
   
707.17 INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANT; EXEMPTIONS.
      The Finance Director is authorized to request the Building Commissioner
to investigate the affairs of any person soliciting contributions for religious
purposes and the affairs of any person exempt from the requirement of a
Certificate of Registration under Section 707.14 and may make public his
written finding. The person being investigated shall make available to the
Finance Director or to any representative designated by the Finance Director,
for such specific purpose, all books, records, and the like, to enable the
Finance Director to fully and fairly inform the public of the work and methods
of such religious solicitation of such persons, provided that five days before
the public release of any findings the Finance Director must first serve a copy
of the findings upon the person investigated and at the time of the release of
his findings he must release a copy of any written statement such person may
file with the Finance Director in explanation, denial or confirmation of such
findings.
(Ord. 78-2021. Passed 10-12-21.)
707.18 INVESTIGATIVE COSTS AND CERTIFICATE FEES.
      At the time of the application for the Certificate of Registration, each
applicant shall deposit with the Building Commissioner a fee as provided in the
General Fee Schedule in Section
701.07 for the purpose of investigation. Certificate fees for each applicant,
solicitor or canvasser shall thereafter be charged as is further provided by
Section
701.07.
(Ord. 78-2021. Passed 10-12-21.)
707.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this Chapter shall be guilty of a second-
degree misdemeanor for the first offense. Each subsequent offense shall be
guilty of a first-degree misdemeanor. Upon conviction of the third offense
their Mobile Food Service Operation Permit, License or Certificate of
Registration shall be permanently revoked.
(Ord. 78-2021. Passed 10-12-21.)
CHAPTER 711
Discontinuing Business Sales
711.01     License required.
711.02     Application.
711.03     Fee; term.
711.04     Adding goods prohibited.
711.05     Investigations; oaths.
711.06     Exceptions.
711.99     Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCE
Fraud - see GEN. OFF.
545.05
 
 
711.01 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall advertise, announce, conduct or hold out by any means or
device any sale of goods, wares or merchandise which is caused or occasioned by
the intention of discontinuing business unless licensed as provided herein.
711.02 APPLICATION.
   Upon application to the Finance Director for a license, the applicant shall
make a full disclosure under oath of the following information:
   (a)   The true name of the owner of the goods, wares or merchandise to be
offered for sale and the name of the operator of the sale if a person other
than the true owner;
   (b)   A full and complete inventory of the quantity, kind and character of
the articles to be offered for sale, which shall be prepared in the following
manner:
      (1)   An itemized listing of all articles and the quantities thereof
remaining unsold which have been in stock on the premises where such sale is to
be conducted for a period of fifteen days or longer prior to the application
for the license;
      (2)   An itemized listing of all articles and the quantities thereof
received in stock on the premises within the fifteen days immediately preceding
the application for the license;
      (3)   An itemized listing of all articles and the quantities thereof
which have been ordered to be placed in stock at such premises during the
pendency of the sale, and the reason for the urgent and expeditious disposal
thereof.
   (c)   Provided, however, that all articles itemized as provided in this
section shall be goods, wares or merchandise purchased by the applicant for
resale on bona fide orders without cancellation privileges and shall not
comprise any articles purchased on consignment.
711.03 FEE; TERM.
    Any license so granted shall be effective for a period of not more than
forty-five days but may be renewed for a period of not more than forty-five
days; provided that proof satisfactory to the Finance Director is first
submitted to him, showing that the stock itemized in the original application
has not been disposed of; nor shall any other such license be granted to the
same person during the period of one year next succeeding the expiration of a
previous license, or renewal of license, granted as aforesaid. The Finance
Director shall receive from the applicant for such license, a fee as provided
in Section
701.07, the General Fee Schedule.
711.04 ADDING GOODS PROHIBITED.
   No license under this chapter shall, during the continuance of such sale,
add any goods, wares or merchandise to the stock described and inventoried in
his original application for a license, and no goods, wares or merchandise
shall be sold at or during the sale, except as described and inventoried in the
original application; and each and every addition of goods, wares or
merchandise to such stock on the premises, and each sale of such goods, wares
or merchandise as shall not have been described and inventoried in such
original application, and each false statement of fact in such application
shall constitute a separate offense.
711.05 INVESTIGATIONS; OATHS.
   The Finance Director shall make or cause to be made such investigations and
inquiries throughout the conduct of any sales as he shall deem advisable to
effectuate the purposes of this chapter, and the Finance Director is authorized
to administer oaths in connection with the taking of testimony pertaining
thereto.
711.06 EXCEPTIONS.
   This chapter shall not apply to sales conducted by sheriffs, constables or
other public or court officials, or to any person acting under the direction or
authority of any court, State or Federal, selling goods, wares and merchandise
in the course of his official duties, nor to sales by licensed auctioneers.
711.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of
the first degree.
CHAPTER 717
Ice Cream and Frozen Desserts
717.01   License required.
717.02   Application and license requirements.
717.03   Transfer of operator license.
717.04   License to be displayed.
717.05   Sales from curb only; sales to minors.
717.06   Exceptions.
717.07   Attendant required for sales from vehicles.
717.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Power to inspect food products - see Ohio R.C. 715.46
Frozen desserts - see Ohio R.C. 3717.51 et seq.
 
 
717.01 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall operate any vehicle, cart or wagon for the sale of ice
creams, custards, sherberts and frozen desserts without first obtaining from
the Director of Finance a license for each vehicle, cart or wagon and the
operator thereof, and paying the required fees as set forth in Section
701.07, the General Fee Schedule. The license shall cover the vehicle, cart or
wagon and its operator and shall be valid only during the calendar year in
which issued.
717.02 APPLICATION AND LICENSE REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   The license and application therefor shall describe the vehicle or
wagon applied for and the person to operate such vehicle.
 
   (b)   The vehicle or wagon applied for must be equipped with two sets of two
flashing lights, one located in the front of the vehicle, and one in the rear.
The flashing lights must be red or amber in color and be activated when the
vehicle is stopped for sale or solicitation of ice cream or frozen desserts.
 
   (c)   The operator shall be eighteen years of age or more, which fact shall
be established by a duly authenticated birth certificate.
 
   (d)   The operator shall provide at his own expense a certificate of health
from a physician designated by the Safety Director.
 
   (e)   The application shall be referred to the Chief of Police who shall
ascertain and certify that such operator has no police record.
 
   (f)   The application and license shall contain a description of the
operator showing his height, weight, age, color of eyes, color of hair and
other pertinent physical attributes which the Safety Director may deem
necessary.
   (g)   A recent photograph of the operator shall be affixed to the license.
   (h)   Ice cream and frozen dessert vendors, before a license may be issued,
shall furnish to the Finance Director, evidence of liability insurance and
property damage in the minimum of one-hundred thousand dollars ($100,000).
Evidence of this insurance shall be endorsed on each license before it is
issued by the Finance Director.
(Ord. 65-1985. Passed 8-12-85.)
717.03 TRANSFER OF OPERATOR LICENSE.
   A license shall not be transferable to another vehicle but may be used by
other operators upon payment of an additional fee after providing the data
hereinbefore required to the Director of Finance for each additional operator.
(Ord. 76-1956. Passed 5-28-56.)
717.04 LICENSE TO BE DISPLAYED.
   The license provided for herein shall be prominently displayed upon the
vehicle, wagon or cart to be used by such operator and for which it is issued.
(Ord. 76-1956. Passed 5-28-56.)
717.05 SALES FROM CURB ONLY; SALES TO MINORS.
   Sales or deliveries made from such vehicles shall be at the curb only. Sales
to children under sixteen years of age when made in the vicinity of their
residences shall be made at the curb in closest proximity to such residence.
(Ord. 76-1956. Passed 5-28-56.)
717.06 EXCEPTIONS.
   This chapter shall not be applicable to similar type sales made by
religious, fraternal or other nonprofit organizations or associations in
connection with a carnival, lawn fete or similar type outdoor gathering when
conducted on a single defined area of private or public premises for the profit
of such organization. (Ord. 76-1956. Passed 5-28-56.)
717.07 ATTENDANT REQUIRED FOR SALES FROM VEHICLES.
   When any person vends or peddles from a vehicle in the public streets and
places in the City and, in the pursuit of such business or activity, children
collect, congregate, assemble or gather about such vehicle for the purpose of
making purchases therefrom, such person so vending and peddling in the pursuit
of such occupation, shall be required to be accompanied by an adult attendant.
Such attendant’s sole duty and occupation shall be to protect and safeguard the
children from injury or hazards from vehicular traffic using such public
streets and public places. The attendant shall maintain a constant lookout for
approaching vehicles, and warn and guard the children from injury therefrom.
(Ord. 60-1999. Passed 8-9-99.)
   
717.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of
the third degree.
CHAPTER 721
Secondhand Dealers
721.01     Definitions; exceptions.
721.02   License required.
721.03   Fees.
721.04   Bond of licensee.
721.05   Registry and receipt books; receipts; inspection of records; daily
reports.
721.06   Minors; intoxicated or suspicious persons.
721.07   Minimum holding period.
721.08   Hours of operation.
721.09   Remedies.
721.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Power to regulate secondhand dealers - see Ohio R.C. 715.61
      Pawnbrokers - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 4727
      Secondhand dealers - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 4737
      Receiving stolen property - see GEN. OFF.
545.18
721.01 DEFINITIONS; EXCEPTIONS.
        (a)   Definitions. As used in this chapter:
      (1)   "Secondhand dealer" means any person, firm or corporation dealing
in or engaging in the purchase or sale of antiques or secondhand articles of
whatever nature, except as specifically excluded herein, including but not
limited to, used bicycles or manufactured articles composed wholly or in part
of new or old precious or semi-precious gold, silver, platinum, copper and/or
other metals or engaging in the reconstruction or remanufacturing or melting or
refining any such articles or reusing the same, video game players, video game
accessories, computers, DVD players, DVDs, cellular phones, tablets,
appliances, and/or any other electronic equipment. Secondhand dealer includes
any person, firm or corporation or agent thereof who or which engages in or
transacts business involving personal property referred to herein whether or
not such conduct is by an established dealer or is a temporary or itinerant or
transient activity, wheresoever situated and when such activity is engaged in
for direct or indirect profit.
      (2)   "Secondhand articles" means any item of personal property or object
of value, previously owned or used, which is not purchased or sold as new.
Secondhand articles do not include property purchased by a licensed,
established merchant from another within or without the City in the normal
course of business.
   (b) Exceptions. Nothing in this chapter shall be deemed to apply to persons,
firms or corporations substantially dealing in the purchase or sale of
secondhand pianos or furniture, books, magazines, rugs, tapestries, burlaps,
paintings, heavy industrial equipment or secondhand automobiles or who deal
with manufacturers or wholesalers for wholesale or retail inventories nor to
exchanges of, returns of or credits of merchandise previously purchased where
the article or articles are exchanged, returned or credited; nor to permitted
house or garage sales or permitted auctions or going out of business sales.
(Ord. 29-2015. Passed 7-13-15.)
721.02 LICENSE REQUIRED.
        (a)   Application.
      (1)   No person, firm or corporation or agent thereof shall directly or
indirectly be permitted to be a secondhand dealer in the City until such
person, firm or corporation has first obtained a license to engage in and carry
on either business.
      (2)   Every applicant for a license shall make an application in writing
on forms provided for such purpose by the City, to the Chief of Police or
designated shift officer in charge. Such application shall set forth the name
under which the business is to be conducted; the name of every person having a
principal interest in the business; the location where the business is to be
carried on; and the nature of such business. The application must be made by
the person or persons who are to carry on the business and shall certify that
no person having an interest therein has been convicted of a felony within the
past ten years. Each applicant shall further certify that he or she has read
and understands the requirements of this chapter.
   (b)   Issuance and Terms of License.
      (1)   Licenses to a secondhand dealer shall be issued annually and expire
annually on December 31.
      (2)   Licenses issued under this chapter shall not be transferred to any
other person and the business may be conducted only at the location for which
the license is issued.
      (3)   A secondhand dealer shall not display any sign or other device in
or about the premises where such business is conducted which in any way
resembles the emblem or sign commonly used by pawnbrokers or which is intended
to give the appearance that the business conducted on such premises is or is
connected with the business of a pawnbroker and calculated to so mislead; nor
shall there be any sign displayed which is calculated to deceive.
         (Ord. 29-2015. Passed 7-13-15.)
721.03  FEES.
        Licenses for carrying on the business of a secondhand dealer shall be
one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each year. Fees for initial licenses issued
hereunder, shall be prorated as of the first day of the month in which the
license is issued.
(Ord. 29-2015. Passed 7-13-15.)
721.04 BOND OF LICENSEE.
   Every licensee under this chapter shall execute and file a bond in the sum
of five thousand dollars ($5,000) with a surety satisfactory to the Director of
Law, assuring that such licensee will conform to the requirements of laws and
ordinances of the City applicable to the licensee. (Ord. 29-2015. Passed 7-13-
15.)
721.05 REGISTRY AND RECEIPT BOOK; RECEIPTS; INSPECTION OF RECORDS; DAILY
REPORTS.
        (a) Each secondhand dealer hereunder shall maintain an accurate
registry and receipt book record and shall list therein each transaction
describing each article which is the subject of the transaction; the purchase
price thereof; the name and place of residence of each seller; the date and
hour when such transaction was made; the name, address, driver's license number
or other identification number from card issued under Ohio R.C. 4507.50 to
4507.52 as well as at least one additional means of identification; the number
or numbers of any serial number, monograms or inscription or other marks that
may appear on the article; a description of the articles or pieces comprising
new or old gem stones, gold, silver, platinum or other metals; from whom such
purchase was made.
        (b)   A receipt for the foregoing information shall be issued to the
seller and a copy of such receipt shall be maintained in substantially bound
form of a size not less than six inches in length and breadth for each
transaction.
        (c)   No entry in such registry and receipt book or upon receipt shall
be erased, obliterated, altered or defaced.
        (d)   No person shall use a fictitious name or address when such person
exchanges or deposits any articles described hereunder in connection with any
transaction with any secondhand dealer in the City.
        (e)   The registry and receipt book shall also contain a record of each
and all resales or other disposition, including the date and hour thereof, of
the articles described therein including transactions by which any gold,
silver, platinum or other metals are caused to be melted, nor is the holder of
a federal license to smelt precious metals exempt from the provisions of this
chapter.
        (f)    Every such secondhand dealer shall on every weekday before the
hour of 12:00 noon, make out a legible and correct copy of the record required
to be kept, containing a clear description of all personal property, bonds,
notes or other securities received on deposit or purchased during the preceding
day, with the hour at which the article was received and a description of the
person or from whom purchased. Such report shall be delivered forthwith to the
Chief of Police, or his or her authorized representative.
(Ord. 29-2015. Passed 7-13-15.)
721.06  MINORS; INTOXICATED OR SUSPICIOUS PERSONS.
        No secondhand dealer shall purchase any article described herein from a
minor; a person who is mentally incompetent; a person appearing to be
intoxicated; a person who is a convicted felon, if such secondhand dealer knows
or has reason to believe that such person is under any such disability; nor
shall such secondhand dealer at any time purchase of any firearm; nor shall any
secondhand dealer employ any person under such disability, or employ a person
who has been convicted of a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude.
(Ord. 29-2015. Passed 7-13-15.)
721.07 MINIMUM HOLDING PERIOD.
        (a) Bonds, notes, securities or any other personal property purchased
any secondhand dealer shall not be sold, redeemed or removed from his place of
business for ten days after the daily report provided in Section
721.05(e) has been delivered.
        
   (b) In addition to the foregoing minimum holding period, every secondhand
dealer shall continue to hold specified goods when ordered to do so by the
Chief of Police or his authorized representative until such police order is
abated by the Chief of Police or his authorized representative or by court
order or by order of the City Law Director/Prosecutor. Such goods shall
thereupon be returnable to the true owner thereof or disposed of as otherwise
directed in such release.
        
   (c) The bond required in Section
721.04 shall specifically apply to the requirements of this section in addition
to the penalty provisions hereinafter set forth.
(Ord. 29-2015. Passed 7-13-15.)
721.08  HOURS OF OPERATION.
        A secondhand dealer hereunder shall not purchase any personal property,
bonds, notes, securities or any articles, property or things before the hour of
8:00 a.m. nor after the hour of 8:00 p.m. (Ord. 29-2015. Passed 7-13-15.)
721.09  REMEDIES.
   Revocation of License. The Chief of Police, upon conviction of a person for
the violation of any of the provisions of this chapter or of any penal statute
relating to secondhand dealers, may revoke his license.
(Ord. 29-2015. Passed 7-13-15.)
721.99  PENALTY.
      Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor
of the first degree and shall be fined not more than one thousand dollars
($1,000) or imprisoned not more than six months, or both, for each offense.
Each day on which a violation occurs or continues shall be deemed a separate
offense.
(Ord. 29-2015. Passed 7-13-15.)

517
 
 
725.01 DEFINITIONS.
    (a)    "Place of business" for purposes of this chapter, and Section
1141.03 of the Planning and Zoning Code means a business within a building or
any part of a building having less than six mechanical, electrically, and/or
electronically operated amusement devices which are used for the purpose of
public entertainment through the operation, use or play, of any table game or
device commonly known as mechanical, electric, and/or electronic games which
are operated by placing therein any coin, plate, disc, plug, key, card, token
of value and/or by the payment of a fee.
 
   (b)    "Establishment" or "amusement center" for purposes of this chapter,
and Section
1141.03 of the Planning and Zoning Code means a business within a building or
any part of a building having more than six mechanical, electrically, and/or
electronically operated amusement devices which are used for the purpose of
public entertainment through the operation, use or play, of any game, table
game and/or devices commonly known as electronic games and which are operated
by placing therein any coin, plate, disc, plug, key, card, token of value and/
or by the payment of a fee.
 
   (c)    "Mechanical, electrically, and/or electronically operated amusement
device" means any coin operated, computer, device or instrument, which upon the
insertion of a coin, plate, disc, plug, key, card, token of value, and/or
payment of a fee, operates or may be operated for use as a game, contest of
skill or amusement, of any description regardless of whether said device is
used for gambling as defined in the Ohio Revised Code. For the purposes of this
chapter, however, nothing contained herein shall apply to the operation of coin
operated pool tables. As used in this chapter, and except where more
specifically delineated, the term "electrical" shall include the term
"electronic" and the term "electrically" shall include the term
"electronically".
   (d)    "Owner" means any person having possession of any mechanical,
electrical, and/or electronic amusement device or any person operating a place
of business, an establishment or amusement center as defined in subsections (a)
and (b) hereof.
(Ord. 25-2010. Passed 4-26-10.)
725.02 TAX; AMOUNT OF LICENSE FEE AND TAX.
   There is hereby levied an annual license fee of five thousand dollars
($5,000.00) as well as a tax of forty dollars ($40.00) per month for each
mechanical, electrically and/or electronically operated amusement device in any
establishment or amusement center as otherwise defined herein. Said tax shall
be collected quarterly and as otherwise provided in Section
703.04 of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Garfield Heights, Ohio.
(Ord. 25-2010. Passed 4-26-10.)
725.03 LICENSES.
   (a)   No person being the owner of an establishment or amusement center
shall display for public patronage or keep for operation by the public, any
mechanical or electrical amusement device without first complying with Section
1141.03 of the Planning and Zoning Code and obtaining a license issued by the
Building Commissioner pursuant to this chapter.
 
   (b)   No person being the owner of an establishment or amusement center
shall display for public patronage or keep for operation by the public, any
mechanical or electrical amusement device without first obtaining a license
issued by the Commissioner pursuant to this chapter.
 
   (c)   Each owner of a business, establishment or amusement center subject to
this chapter shall, in addition to the license fee delineated in this section,
pay any additional fees provided in Section
701.07 per year for each electrical, electronic or mechanical amusement device
located on such premises.
 
   (d)   No transfer of a license, either as to person or place, shall be
permitted except with the written consent of the Commissioner, which consent
shall be endorsed upon the license.
 
   (e)   No license shall be issued until an application is submitted to the
Commissioner, which application shall, among other things, state:
      (1)   The name and address, age and birth date of the applicant;
      (2)   The location where the mechanical or electrical amusement devices
are to be displayed or operated and the business conducted therein;
      (3)   A description of the machine or machines to be covered by the
license, its mechanical features, the name of the manufacturer and the serial
number of the machine;
      (4)   The name of the owner or owners of the premises wherein the devices
are to be displayed or operated;
      (5)   The name of the owner or owners of the business conducted therein;
      (6)   The name of the owner of the machine, if the person is different
from the applicant; and
      (7)   Whether or not the applicant or the owner of the machines has been
convicted of a gambling offense of for the sale or conviction of a drug offense
in the last ten years prior to the date of application.
(Ord. 64-1982. Passed 1-3-83; Ord. 25-2010. Passed 4-26-10.)
725.04 LICENSE ISSUANCE.
   (a)   If the applicant for a license has filed the proper application and
has paid the proper fee as specified in Section
725.02 and the Building Commissioner is satisfied that all information
requested is properly given and that after inspection by the Building
Department that all wiring and connections meet the then present electrical
code standards, and the applicant meets all other applicable fire and building
code requirements of the City, then a license shall be issued.
 
   (b)   The license shall be displayed in a prominent place in the business
establishment. The license issued for each mechanical or electrical amusement
device shall be displayed on each such device. It shall be the duty of the
owner to display such licenses during the period covered by the license.
(Ord. 64-1982. Passed 1-3-83; Ord. 25-2010. Passed 4-26-10.)
725.05 PERIODIC INSPECTION.
   The owner of every place of business, establishment or amusement center
providing mechanical or electrically operated amusement devices, as defined in
Section
725.01, shall at all times permit access to the Building Commissioner or his
designee for the purpose of periodically inspecting both the premises and the
mechanical or electrical amusement devices.
(Ord. 64-1982. Passed 1-3-83; Ord. 25-2010. Passed 4-26-10.)
725.06 MINORS; CURFEW RESTRICTIONS.
   (a)   No person under the age of eighteen years of age shall be permitted to
operate a mechanical or electrical amusement device before 3:00 p.m. on school
days unless accompanied by that person's parent or legal guardian. It shall be
the duty of the owner to determine if, in fact, school is in session for the
individual operating, or wishing to operate, such device.
 
   (b)   It shall be the duty of the owner to prominently display in his place
of business the curfew laws of the City. It shall further be the duty of the
owner to ascertain if his patrons are violating such curfew laws, and if so, to
eject them from the establishment.
(Ord. 64-1982. Passed 1-3-83; Ord. 25-2010. Passed 4-26-10.)
725.07 GENERAL PROVISIONS.
   (a)   No owner shall permit the consumption of intoxicants or alcoholic
beverages by any person on the premises unless such owner holds a proper permit
from the Ohio State Liquor Control Board.
 
   (b)   All places of business, establishments and amusement centers subject
to this chapter shall, during hours of operation, provide adult management over
the age of eighteen years.
 
   (c)   The owner of any place of business, establishment or amusement center
subject to this chapter shall provide necessary security personnel to police
the interior and exterior portion of the business establishment.
(Ord. 64-1982. Passed 1-3-83; Ord. 25-2010. Passed 4-26-10.)
725.08 GAMBLING.
   (a)   The owner of any place of business, establishment or amusement center
subject to this chapter shall prominently display a sign indicating that
gambling is prohibited. It shall further be indicated on the sign that it shall
be considered to be a gambling offense if a player agrees to pay for the game
of another upon the loss of a game.
 
   (b)   No electronic or mechanical device shall be permitted that has as its
object the skill of winning at the playing of cards, dice, craps or roulette.
(Ord. 64-1982. Passed 1-3-83; Ord. 25-2010. Passed 4-26-10.)
725.09 LICENSE REVOCATION; APPEAL; BOARD OF REVIEW.
   The Building Commissioner may suspend or revoke any license issued pursuant
to this chapter for the direct or indirect violation of any of the provisions
hereof. In the event that the Commissioner suspends or revokes any license, the
owner may within ten days appeal such suspension or revocation to the Mayor. If
the Mayor upholds such suspension or revocation, the owner may appeal to a
Board of Review within ten days from the Mayor's decision, consisting of one
member of Council, the Building Commissioner and the Director of Law. The
decision of the Board of Review shall be final.
(Ord. 64-1982. Passed 1-3-83; Ord. 25-2010. Passed 4-26-10.)
725.99 PENALTY.
   In addition to the revocation of license provisions in Section
725.08, whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor of the third degree.
(Ord. 64-1982. Passed 1-3-83.)
CHAPTER 727
Musical Devices
727.01     Definitions.
727.02     License and registration.
727.03     Issuance of license.
727.04     Application information.
727.05     Registration sticker.
727.06     License revocation; hearing.
727.07     Prohibited uses.
727.08     Records to be kept.
727.99     Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Using slugs - see GEN. OFF.
545.11
Tampering with coin machine - see GEN. OFF.
545.12
Special uses - see P. & Z.
1141.03
 
 
727.01 DEFINITIONS.
   (a)   "Mechanical musical instrument" as used in this chapter means any
amusement machine, apparatus or device designed or constructed for the purpose
of producing, reproducing or playing any musical or vocal tone or combination
of tones, the operation or use of which instrument is permitted, controlled,
allowed or made possible by the deposit or placing of any coin, plate, disc,
token or key into any slot, crevice or other opening in such instrument.
 
   (b)   "Premises which are open to the public", or similar words as used in
this chapter, includes clubs, private clubs, headquarters, and meeting places
of fraternal and other societies, associations and bodies, and all other
public places.
727.02 LICENSE AND REGISTRATION.
   No exhibitor or owner shall maintain, operate or permit to be maintained or
operated in, upon or about any premises which are open to the public any
mechanical musical instrument, unless a license and registration therefor shall
have been first obtained from the Finance Director.
727.03 ISSUANCE OF LICENSE.
   The Finance Director is authorized and empowered to establish, adopt and
enforce, or cause to be enforced, such rules and regulations governing the
issuance of the licenses required under this chapter as he may deem reasonable
and necessary and not inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter.
727.04 APPLICATION INFORMATION.
   Application for the license shall be made to the Finance Director upon such
blank forms as shall be prescribed therefor. On such application the applicant
shall state his name, whether an individual, partnership or corporation, and if
a partnership, the names and addresses of the partners composing the same, the
addresses at which it is desired to maintain and operate the mechanical musical
instrument, the nature of the business conducted at such place, the make, name,
model, serial number and other identifying information with reference to the
particular mechanical musical instrument which it is desired to operate, the
name and address of the owner of such instrument, and such other and further
information as the Finance Director may require.
727.05 REGISTRATION STICKER.
   Upon the filing of the application and the payment of a licensee fee as
provided in Section
701.07, the General Fee Schedule, the Finance Director shall issue to the
applicant a license which shall entitle the license to maintain and operate, at
the premises mentioned in the application, the mechanical musical instrument or
instruments described in the application, subject to the terms and conditions
of this chapter.
   At the time of issuing such license, the Finance Director shall also issue
to the licensee a registration slip or sticker for each mechanical musical
instrument described in the application.
727.06 LICENSE REVOCATION; HEARING.
   The license of any person violating any of the terms of this chapter or any
of the rules and regulations established and adopted by the Finance Director
shall be revoked by the Finance Director. The Finance Director is authorized
and empowered to deny, for reasonable cause, applications for licenses.
   The Finance Director shall notify such licensee of any hearing involving the
denial or revocation of such license. Such notification shall be by registered
mail directed to the last address of the licensee on file.
727.07 PROHIBITED USES.
   No person shall play, produce or reproduce upon any mechanical musical
instrument any obscene selection or rendition. No person shall use or permit to
be used or maintained any mechanical musical instrument in such manner as to
disturb the peace and quiet of the neighborhood.
727.08 RECORDS TO BE KEPT.
   The Finance Director shall keep and maintain on file in his office a full
and complete list of all licensees licensed under the provisions of this
chapter, and also a full and complete list of all mechanical instruments which
are registered under the provisions of this chapter.
727.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor
of the fourth degree.
CHAPTER 733
Private Investigators and Agencies
733.01     Definitions.
733.02     License required.
733.03     Exceptions.
733.04     Application for license; requirements.
733.05     License issuance or denial.
733.06     License fees; display; identification.
733.07     Revocation of license.
733.08     Bond and insurance.
733.09     Reports filed with Police Chief.
733.10     Badge.
733.11     Radios.
733.12     Oath.
733.99     Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Private investigators - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 4749
Private police officer training program - see OAC CH. 109:2-3
Private investigator licensing - see OAC Ch. 1301:4-5
 
 
733.01 DEFINITIONS.
   (a)   The words "private investigation" as used herein means the conducting
or making, for hire, of any investigation for the purpose of obtaining evidence
or testimony to be used before investigating committees, boards of award or
arbitration or in the trial of civil or criminal cases, or obtaining
information with reference to any of the following matters:
      (1)   Crimes and offenses, or wrongs done or threatened;
      (2)   The habits, conduct, movements, associates,
transactions,reputation, character or location of persons, firms or
corporations;
      (3)   The credibility of witnesses or other persons;
      (4)   The location or recovery of lost or stolen property;
      (5)   The causes, origin or responsibility for fires, accidents or
injuries to real or personal property, or strikes and labor difficulties.
   (b)   "Private investigation agency" means a person, firm or corporation
employing, in the private investigation business, one or more private
investigators.
 
   (c)   "Private investigator" means any person who engages in private
investigation for hire, whether self-employed or employed by a private
investigation agency.
733.02 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall operate a private investigation agency, or act as a private
investigator within the City unless duly licensed as provided herein.
   No person shall knowingly employ or hire the services of an unlicensed
private investigator or private investigation agency.
733.03 EXCEPTIONS.
   The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to the following:
   (a)   Employment as regularly appointed police officers, regularly appointed
peace officers, or law enforcement agents of the United States, the State of
Ohio, or political subdivisions thereof.
   (b)   Off-duty employment as regularly appointed police officers of the City
when approved by the Chief of Police or as regularly appointed members of the
Cuyahoga County Sheriff's office when approved by the Sheriff.
   (c)   The protection of persons or property being transported in interstate
or intrastate commerce.
   (d)   Persons employed in private business establishments, premises or
structures other than places of amusement, recreation and entertainment where
the major portion of such employment is confined to services within such
private business establishments, premises or structures.
   (e)   The investigation and adjustment of insurance losses.
   (f)   Attorneys at law in the practice of their profession.
   (g)   Agencies whose exclusive business is the furnishing of information as
to the business and financial standing and credit responsibility of persons,
firms and corporations, or personal habits and financial responsibility of
applicants or claimants with respect to insurance, indemnity bonds or
commercial credit.
   (h)   Any person particularly skilled as a workman or in the knowledge of a
particular business, whose employment by any one agency shall not exceed sixty
days in one calendar year. The identity of such person shall be furnished to
the Chief of Police.
733.04 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   Application for private investigation agency or private investigator
licenses shall be made to the Safety Director on forms approved by him.
Applicants shall be fingerprinted and photographed at the Identification
Section of the Police Division.
 
   (b)   Licenses shall be issued only to United States citizens of full age
who have resided in Cuyahoga County for not less than one year immediately
preceding such application. Licenses shall not be issued to persons who have
been adjudged insane, convicted of a felony or of a crime or offense involving
violence or moral turpitude, or found upon investigation by the Chief of Police
not to be of good character.
 
   (c)   Any person found upon such investigation not to be of good character
shall be entitled, upon request, to a copy of such adverse finding, and shall
have the right of appeal as provided in Section
701.06.
733.05 LICENSE ISSUANCE OR DENIAL.
   When the Safety Director is satisfied that there is a necessity therefor,
and that the applicant is of good moral character, competency and integrity,
and has complied with all the requirements of this chapter, then, upon payment
of the proper license fee, he shall issue licenses for private investigators
and private investigation agencies.
   In the event that the Safety Director shall decline to approve such license,
the person adversely affected shall have the right of appeal as provided in
Section
701.06.
733.06 LICENSE FEES; DISPLAY; IDENTIFICATION.
   (a)   All licenses granted under this chapter shall expire on June 30 of
each year, unless sooner revoked. Fees as set forth in Section
701.07, the General Fee Schedule, shall be paid to the Finance Director.
 
   (b)   The license for a private investigator shall be in such form as to
contain a true photograph and right thumb print of the licensee, his name,
address, physical description and signature, and shall be carried by the
licensee during his hours of employment or duty, and shall be subject at all
times to inspection by any member of the Police Division.
 
   (c)   The license for a private investigation agency shall be in a form
prescribed by the Safety Director and shall be displayed at the licensee's
office.
733.07 REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   The Finance Director is authorized to suspend or revoke any license granted
hereunder and to refuse to grant or renew any license to any person by reason
of the violation of any provision of this chapter.
   Any person, adversely affected by any act of the Finance Director under this
section shall have the right of appeal as provided in Section
701.06.
733.08 BOND AND INSURANCE.
   Each applicant shall file with the Finance Director an approved fidelity
bond in the principal sum of one thosand dollars ($1,000) in favor of the City,
for the benefit of any person damaged by the dishonest or fraudulent act of the
applicant. Such bond shall be maintained in full force and in the full
principal amount at all times, and shall provide that it shall not be cancelled
or revoked until ten days after written notice of intention so to cancel or
revoke has been given to the Finance Director.
   In addition to the bond hereinabove required, each applicant shall file with
the Finance Director an approved policy of public liability insurance including
coverage for false arrest, having coverage limits of ten thousand dollars
($10,000) per person, twenty thousand dollars ($20,000) per accident, and five
thousand dollars ($5,000) property damage. Such policy of insurance shall be
maintained in full force and full coverage at all times and shall provide that
it shall not be cancelled or revoked until ten days after written notice of
intention so to cancel or revoke has been given to the Finance Director.
   The insolvency or bankruptcy of the licensee shall not operate to release
the surety or insurer from liability upon the bond or policy of insurance.
733.09 REPORTS FILED WITH POLICE CHIEF.
   Every private investigation agency licensee shall immediately submit to the
Chief of Police in writing the names of all persons in its employ and
thereafter the names of all persons hired or discharged.
   Licensees shall report all police action taken, except routine patrol duty
to the Chief of Police within twelve hours, and shall report as soon as
practicable to the Chief of Police all property found or recovered.
   Licensees shall report all knowledge or information of any crime to the
Division of Police.
733.10 BADGE.
   Licensed private investigators may carry badges approved by the Chief of
Police which design shall differ from that worn by members of the Division of
Polce.
733.11 RADIOS.
   Vehicles equipped with radios capable of being tuned to the City's police
frequency shall not be used without knowledge of the Chief of Police and
written approval of the Safety Director.
733.12 OATH.
   Upon issuance of a license, the licensee shall take and subscribe to an oath
or affirmation similar to that administered to police officers of the City.
733.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of
the first degree.
CHAPTER 735
Private Patrol Watchmen and Agencies
735.01     Definitions.
735.02     License required.
735.03     Exceptions.
735.04     Application for license; requirements.
735.05     Bond and insurance.
735.06     License issuance or denial.
735.07     License fees; display; identification.
735.08     Revocation of license.
735.09     Radios.
735.10     Oath.
735.11     Uniform and badge.
735.12     Vehicles.
735.13     Reports filed with Police Chief.
735.99     Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Private investigators - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 4749
Private polce officer training program - see OAC Ch. 109:2-3
Private investigator licensing - see OAC Ch. 1301:4-5
 
 
735.01 DEFINITIONS.
   (a)   "Private patrol agency" means any person, firm or corporation, who
employs, furnishes or provides the service of a private patrol watchman.
 
   (b)   "Private patrol watchman" means any person in uniform or otherwise,
who, for hire or reward, shall guard or protect any structure, premises,
property or persons, by patrolling on foot or in any vehicle upon any street,
highway, alley or other public place in the City and includes any person who,
for hire or reward, shall be employed to guard, protect or maintain peace and
order in or about any structure, premises or property, which is operated,
maintained or conducted as a dance hall, theater or any other place of
amusement, recreation or entertainment frequented by the public, including
liquor establishments licensed under State statutes.
735.02 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall operate a private patrol agency or act as private patrol
watchman within the City unless duly licensed by this chapter.
   No person shall knowingly employ or hire the services of an unlicensed
private patrol agency or private patrol watchman.
735.03 EXCEPTIONS.
   This chapter shall not apply to the folloing:
   (a)   Employment as regularly appointed police officers, regularly appointed
peace officers or law enforcement agents of the United States, the State of
Ohio or political subdivisions thereof.
   (b)   Off-duty employment as regularly appointed police officers of the City
when approved by the Chief of Police or as regularly appointed members of the
Cuyahoga County Sheriff's office when approved by the Sheriff.
   (c)   Employment as guards or watchmen engaged in the protection of persons
or property being transported in interstate or intrastate commerce.
   (d)   Employent as guards or watchmen employed in private business
establishments, premises or structures, where the major portion of such
employment is confined to services within such private business establishments,
premises or structures, and where such establishments, premises or structures
are not places of amusement, recreation or entertainment frequented by the
public, including liquor establishments licensed under State statutes.
735.04 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   Application for private patrol agency or private patrol watchman
licenses shall be made to the Safety Director on forms approved by him.
Applicants shall be fingerprinted and photographed at the Identification
Section of the Police Division.
 
   (b)   Licenses shall be issued only to United States citizens of full age
who have resided in Cuyahoga County for not less than one year immediately
preceding such application. Licenses shall not be issued to persons who have
been adjudged insane, convicted of a felony or of a crime or offense involving
violence or moral turpitude or fraud upon investigation by the Chief of Police
not to be of good character.
 
   (c)   Any person found upon such investigation not to be of good character
shall be entitled, upon request, to a copy of such adverse finding, and shall
have the right of appeal as provided in Section
701.06.
735.05 BOND AND INSURANCE.
   Each applicant shall file with the Finance Director an approved fidelity
bond in the principal sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000) in favor of the
City, for the benefit of any person damaged by the dishonest or fraudulent act
of the applicant. Such bond shall be maintained in full force and in the full
principal amount at all times, and shall provide that it shall not be cancelled
or revoked until ten days after written notice of intention so to cancel or
revoke has been given to the Finance Director.
   In additon to the bond hereinabove required, each applicant shall file with
the Finance Director an approved policy of public liability insurance including
coverage for false arrest, having coverage limits of ten thousand dollars
($10,000) per person, twenty thousand dollars ($20,000) per accident, and five
thousand dollars ($5,000) property damage. Such policy of insurance shall be
maintained in full force and full coverage at all times, and shall provide that
it shall not be cancelled or revoked until after ten days written notice of
intention to cancel or revoke has been given to the Finance Director.
   The insolvency or bankruptcy of the licensee shall not operate to release
the surety or insurer from liability upon the bond or policy of insurance.
735.06 LICENSE ISSUANCE OR DENIAL.
   When the Safety Director is satisfied that there is a necessity therefor,
and that the applicant is of good moral character, compentency and integrity,
and has complied with all requirements of this chapter, then, upon payment of
the proper license fee, he shall issue licenses for private patrol watchmen and
private patrol agencies.
   In the event that the Safety Director shall decline to approve such license,
the person adversely affected shall have the right of appeal as provided in
Section
701.06.
735.07 LICENSE FEES; DISPLAY; IDENTIFICATION.
   (a)   All licenses granted under this chapter shall expire on June 30 of
each year, unless sooner revoked. Fees as set forth in Section
701.07, the General Fee Schedule shall be paid to the Finance Director.
 
   (b)   The license for a private patrol watchman shall be in such form as to
contain a true photograph and rightthumb print of the licensee, his name,
address, physical description and signature, and shall be carried by the
licensee during his hours of employment or duty and shall be subject at all
times to inspection by any member of the Police Division.
 
   (c)   The license for a private patrol agency shall be in a form as
prescribed by the Safety Director and shall be displayed at the licensee's
office.
735.08 REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   The Safety Director is authorized to suspend or revoke any license granted
hereunder and to refuse to grant or renew any license to any person by reason
of the violation of any provision of this chapter.
   Any person adversely affected by any act of the Director under this section
shall have the right of appeal as provided in Section
701.06.
735.09 RADIOS.
   Vehicles equipped with radios capable of being tuned to the City's police
frequency shall not be used without the knowledge of the Chief of Police and
written approval of the Safety Director.
735.10 OATH.
   Upon issuance of a license, the licensee shall take and subscribe to an oath
or affirmation, similar to that administered to police officers of the City.
735.11 UNIFORM AND BADGE.
   Licensed private patrol watchmen may wear a uniform and a badge of a design
approved by the Chief of Police, which shall differ from those worn by members
of the Division of Police.
735.12 VEHICLES.
   Licensees may identify the vehicles used while on patrol but only in a
manner approved by the Chief of Police.
735.13 REPORTS FILED WITH POLICE CHIEF.
   Every private patrol agency licensee shall immediately submit to the Chief
of Police in writing the names of all persons in its employ and thereafter the
names of all persons hired and/or discharged.
   Licensees shall report all police action taken, except routine patrol duty,
to the Chief within twelve hours, and shall report as soon as practicable to
the Chief all property found or recovered.
   Licensees shall report all knowledge or information of any crime to the
Division of Police.
735.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of
the first degree.

701
